Notes.Text:
This update for jhead fixes the following security issues:

- CVE-2016-3822: jhead remote attackers to execute arbitrary code or cause a
  denial of service (out-of-bounds access) via crafted EXIF data (bsc#1108480).
- CVE-2018-16554: The ProcessGpsInfo function may have allowed a remote
  attacker to cause a denial-of-service attack or unspecified other impact via a
  malicious JPEG file, because of inconsistency between float and double in a
  sprintf format string during TAG_GPS_ALT handling (bsc#1108480).
Notes.Title: Details

Notes.Text: The CVRF data is provided by SUSE under the Creative Commons License 4.0 with Attribution (CC-BY-4.0).
Notes.Title: Terms of Use

Relationships.RelatesToProductReference: SUSE Package Hub for SUSE Linux Enterprise 15

Vulnerabilities.Description: exif.c in Matthias Wandel jhead 2.87, as used in libjhead in Android 4.x before 4.4.4, 5.0.x before 5.0.2, 5.1.x before 5.1.1, and 6.x before 2016-08-01, allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code or cause a denial of service (out-of-bounds access) via crafted EXIF data, aka internal bug 28868315.

ProductID: SUSE Package Hub for SUSE Linux Enterprise 15:jhead-3.00-bp150.3.3.1

Vulnerabilities.Description: The ProcessGpsInfo function of the gpsinfo.c file of jhead 3.00 may allow a remote attacker to cause a denial-of-service attack or unspecified other impact via a malicious JPEG file, because of inconsistency between float and double in a sprintf format string during TAG_GPS_ALT handling.

ProductID: SUSE Package Hub for SUSE Linux Enterprise 15:jhead-3.00-bp150.3.3.1
